UPDATES AND REVIEWS
(40 CFR § 68.190)

The Risk Management Plan for TDI will be reviewed and updated at minimum according to the following schedule:

1.	Every five (5) years from the date of the initial submission or most recent update
2.	Within six (6) months of a change which requires an updated PHA
3.	Within six (6) months of a change that requires a revised off site consequence analysis
4.	Within six (6) months of a change that alters the applicable program level

MarChem Southeast will submit a de-registration within six months of when the process no longer becomes subject to the RMP regulations.

Company History:

MarChem Southeast designs and manufactures custom polyurethane and PVC formulations for a wide variety of industrial applications. MarChem Southeast does not produce any part, but rather supplies these formulations in a liquid state to end product fabricators. MarChem Southeast has a trained technical and quality control staff which develops all of our products, follows then through the manufacturing process and tests them for quality prior to shipment. This site has been in operation for more than thirty years. 

The Covered Process:

The Delivery, Storage and Use of Toluene Diisocyanate to manufacture Urethane Binders

Toluene Diisocyanate (TDI) is delivered to MSE via over the road tanker cars. Once at MSE, the tanker is unloaded into a storage tank with a maximum capacity of 7500 gallons. The TDI is then pumped into one of two batch units on site which are used to produce polyurethane pre-polymers or quasi pre-polymers. Each of these units has a capacity of 500 ¿ 6000 gallons. These pre-polymers are manufactured by reacting long chain polyols with Toluene Diisocyanate (TDI) in a 2:1 molar ratio to produce NCO terminated high viscosity pre-polymers. These pre-polymers can be chain extended by the end product fabricators with water, short chain polyols or diamines to produce molecular weight polymers. Quasi pre-polymers are manufactured by reacting only part of the long chain polyol with Toluene Diisocyanate which improves mixing, reduces volatility, improves compatibility, improves the mix ratio balance, reduces the exotherm and helps match viscosity differences.

Both batch units have hot oil jackets which control the temperature of the reaction. A MDA Scientific (Model TLD-1) monitor with a TDI keys is used to monitor the levels of TDI in the air. The monitor sounds an alarm if the atmospheric concentration of TDI exceeds 5 ppb. All MSE personnel who handle TDI, operate the covered process or perform quality control tests on TDI based material

s are required to wear personal TDI monitoring badges. These badges are checked each shift that TDI is used to determine if any employee has been exposed to elevated levels of TDI.


Five Year Accident History:

MarChem Southeast has not had an accidental release of Toluene Diisocyanate during the last five years.




Program Status (40 CFR §68.10):

MarChem Southeast has several public receptors within one tenth of a mile of the covered process and therefore does not fit the eligibility requirements of Program 1. The covered process is in NAICS code 325991 and is not subject to the requirements of the process safety management standard (29 CFR 1910.119). Therefore, the covered process falls under the Program 2 requirements of 49 CFR Subpart C.

Management System (40 CFR §68.15):

MarChem Southeast¿s management system for the RMP for TDI is a team approach. The team consists of the Laboratory Manager, the Vice-President of Operations, The Maintenance Supervisor, and the individual Shift Supervisors. 

The Laboratory Manager has the overall responsibility for the management of the RMP at MarChem Southeast. The Laboratory Manager is also responsible for the release scenarios, incident investigations and the RMP review and updates required under this RMP. The Laboratory Manager is assisted in his tasks by the VP Operations who is responsible for the hazard review, safety information, compliance audits and training program under this RMP and the initial submission of this RMP. The Maintenance Supervisor is responsible for the maintenance program for the covered process. The Shift Supervisors who will handle emergency response functions when the Laboratory Manager is not onsite.


PROGRAM 2 PREVENTION PROGRAM 

Safety Information (40 CFR § 68.48):

The Material Safety Data Sheet for Toluene Diisocyanate (TDI) CAS # 26471-62-5 is located in this Risk Management Program binder. MSE has requested that the supplier send MSE updated MSDS as they become available.

The storage

tank for TDI at MSE is designed to hold 7500 gallons (76,350 lbs) at absolute capacity. Because of the usage pattern of TDI at MSE and the delivery schedule for TDI to MSE, the maximum amount of TDI in the storage tank at any one time will be 6000 gallons (61,000 lbs). The largest amount of TDI stored to date is 5900 gallons (60,000 lbs). 

Changes in the composition of the raw material (TDI), the equipment, the process or operating procedures or information received from suppliers or MSE¿s own experience will be cause for an assessment as to the effect of the change on the RMP.

Hazard Review (40 CFR§ 68.50)

MarChem Southeast has utilized a ¿What If¿ method to determine the hazards associated with the covered process and TDI itself. This method covered opportunities for equipment malfunction and human error that could lead to an accidental release. As part of this review, any problems identified in the ¿What If¿ worksheets shall be resolved and the resolution documented in a timely manner. 

Operating Procedures (40 CFR § 68.520

Operating procedures for the delivery, storage and use of Toluene Diisocyanate (TDI) have been developed and are part of the Work Instructions (WI) in use at MarChem Southeast. 

Training (40 CFR § 68.54)

Each operator of the covered process (or part of the covered process), personnel who will be involved in the maintenance of the process and the laboratory personnel who will be evaluating or testing TDI containing material will be trained in the safe use and handling of TDI and any emergency procedures in the case of a release.

This training will be done prior to any employee being assigned to the covered process or any part of the process. Refresher training will be given at least every three years. Whenever the process undergoes a major change, all affected employees will be trained in any new or updated procedures. 

Maintenance (40 CFR § 68.56)

The equipment used in the covered process is part of the preventive maintenance (PM) p

rogram that is part of MarChem Southeast¿s Quality Management System (QMS). The PM program covers all major equipment identified in the Hazard Assessment and follows any applicable guidelines from the equipment manufacturer. All maintenance personnel will be trained in the hazards of the process and the requirements of the PM program. Any maintenance contractor will be evaluated as to their ability to perform the necessary maintenance and follow established safety requirements for the process.

Compliance Audits (40 CFR § 68.58)

Compliance audits will be performed at least every three years. The auditor will use a check list to determine compliance. These audits will be performed by personnel with knowledge of the process and will be reviewed by the operator or his designee(s) to determine appropriate responses to any findings uncovered by the audit in a timely manner.

Incident Investigation (40 CFR § 68.60)

MarChem Southeast will investigate any incident that results in or could have resulted in a catastrophic release of TDI. The incident will be investigated by the Risk Management Team within 48 hours of the incident. The team will issue a report that will include at a minimum: 

1.	The date of the incident
2.	The date the investigation began
3.	A description of the incident
4.	Contributing factors to the incident
5.	Any recommendations resulting form the investigation

Any investigation report shall be kept on file for five (5) years.MarChem Southeast shall promptly address all of the findings and recommendations that result from the investigation. All findings and changes resulting from the investigation shall be reviewed will all affected personnel
